slides.title: EcAZ Phage Project Progress
slides.subtitle: Group Meeting Report
slides.notes:
Good morning/afternoon, everyone! Today I'll present the latest progress on our EcAZ phage project.

The goal is to isolate bacteriophages that can infect EcAZ E. coli from sewage samples. We use two host strains: wild-type W strain and OVA-expressing R strain.

I'll cover phage isolation, host range, titer determination, and killing curves.

slides.title: Phage Isolation & Characterization Summary
slides.footnote: R1: Only narrow-host-range | R2: Turbid plaques (temperate) | R3: Largest plaques
slides.notes:
This table summarizes the key characteristics of our five phage isolates.

Three important findings:

First, R1 is the only narrow-host-range phage - it can only infect R strain, not W strain. This may be related to the OVA protein on R strain surface.

Second, R2 is the only phage producing turbid plaques, suggesting it may be a temperate phage.

Third, R3 has the largest plaques - over 3mm in diameter, more than 15 times larger than R1.

slides.title: Plaque Morphology Photos
slides.notes:
Here are the plaque photos of all five phages.

You can clearly see the differences:

R1 plaques are extremely small, barely visible.

R2 shows turbid plaques - a hallmark of temperate phages.

R3 has the largest and clearest plaques. Note the size heterogeneity due to spreading behavior.

W1 and W2 have intermediate-sized clear plaques.

slides.title: Killing Curves: MOI Optimization
labels: R Strain Killing Curves (R1, R2, R3)
slides.notes:
These are the key results from our killing curve experiments.

Left panel shows W strain results: W1 at MOI=10 shows the fastest lysis at 56 minutes; W2 at MOI=1 is most efficient.

Right panel shows R strain results: R3 performs best - all MOIs achieve lysis within 30-45 minutes, making it the most efficient killer among all five phages. R1 shows moderate efficiency. R2 shows almost no lysis, confirming its temperate nature.

Conditions: 37°C, BioTek Epoch 2, 12-hour continuous monitoring.

slides.title: Killing Curve Results Summary
conclusions: **R3**: Lysis within 30 min at any MOI → Top candidate for phage therapy
**R2**: No lysis → Confirmed as temperate phage
slides.notes:
This table summarizes the key findings from the killing curve experiments.

Two main points:

First, R3 is the best killer - fastest lysis (30 minutes), works well across all MOIs including MOI=0.01. This makes it the top candidate for phage therapy applications.

Second, R2 shows almost no lysis effect. Combined with its turbid plaque morphology, we can confirm R2 is a temperate phage that enters the lysogenic cycle rather than lytic cycle.

slides.title: Conclusions & Future Plans
next_steps: One-step growth curve (latent period, burst size)
slides.notes:
Summary of our main findings:

We successfully isolated five bacteriophages from sewage that can infect EcAZ E. coli.

R1 is the only narrow-host-range phage, possibly recognizing an OVA-related receptor.

R2 is confirmed as a temperate phage - useful for studying lysogeny mechanisms.

R3 has the best killing efficiency - an excellent candidate for phage therapy.

Next steps: one-step growth curves, genome sequencing, and TEM imaging.

Thank you all for your attention!

Questions and discussions are welcome. Thank you!
